markdown: ## 1978-79 Previews John Dexter directing. The sets and lighting are by Josef Svoboda, the costumes by Jan Skalicky, and the choreography by Pavel Smok. The principals include Teresa Stratas as Marenka, Nicolai Gedda as Jenik, Jon Vickers as Vasek, and Martti Talvela as Kecal. The production is underwritten in part by a generous gift of the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation. The season's third new production will be Donizetti's *Don Pasquale*, with Beverly Sills as Norina, Gabriel Bacquier in the title role, Nicolai Gedda as Ernesto, and Håkan Hagegård making his Met debut as Dr. Malatesta. Also making his debut will be the conductor, Nicola Rescigno. The staging is by John Dexter, with sets and costumes by Desmond Heeley and lighting by Gil Wechsler. The premiere, a Guild Benefit, will take place on December 7th. Verdi's Don Carlo will open on February 5, 1979, also at a Guild Benefit. The cast will include Renata Scotto as Elisabeth, Marilyn Horne as Eboli, Veriano Luchetti in his Met debut as Don Carlo, Sherrill Milnes as Rodrigo, and Nicolai Ghiaurov as King Philip. The conductor is James Levine, and the director John Dexter, with sets by David Reppa, costumes by Ray Diffen, and lighting by Gil Wechsler. The production is a deeply appreciated gift of Mrs. Donald D. Harrington. The Season's final new production will be Wagner's Der Fliegende Holländer, opening on March 8, 1979. Carol Neblett will make her Metropolitan debut as Senta and José van Dam will sing the Dutchman, with William Lewis as Erik and Paul Plishka as Daland. ## Revivals Nineteen operas will be revived during the 1978-79 season. Seven will be held over from the 93rd season: Tchaikovsky's *Eugene Onegin*, Puccini's *Madama Butterfly* and *Tosca*, Verdi's *Otello*, *Rigoletto*, and *La Traviata*, and Wagner's *Tannhäuser*. The 12 works returning after an absence of one season or more will be: Beethoven's <::A black and white photograph shows two images. The main image depicts a man, Jon Vickers, in costume as Otello, kneeling on a stage. He is wearing a long, patterned robe and has a beard, looking upwards with a dramatic expression. Behind him are two large, ornate, circular shields. In the bottom right corner, an inset photograph shows a woman, Marilyn Horne, from the chest up, looking slightly to the right. She has short, dark hair and is wearing a necklace. : photograph::> Verdi's Otello, with Jon Vickers in the title role, was revived during the current season, and will return in 1978-79. (Set designer: Franco Zeffirelli; costume designer: Peter J. Hall) Mezzo Marilyn Horne will be heard next season as Eboli in Don Carlo, a new production which opens on February 5, 1979. <::A circular, ornate metal object with a central raised boss and an intricately patterned border, resembling a shield or decorative plate.: figure::> ## Debuts In addition to the debut artists listed above with the new productions, the following musicians will be heard for the first time at the Met next season: conductors Yuri Siminov and Calvin Simmons; sopranos Makvala Kash-rashvili, Carol Malone, Mariana Niculescu, and May Sandoz; tenors Vladimir Atlantov, Peter Hofmann, and Seth McCoy; baritones Christian Boesch, Dale Duesing, Yuri Mazurok, and Siegmund Nimsgern; and basses Michael Devlin and Kurt Moll. The publication of this Newsletter is made possible by a special grant from Pioneer High Fidelity. Metropolitan Opera Lincoln Center New York, New York 10023 <::attestation: Postage Meter Mark POSTAGE PAID Readable Text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y., FIRST CLASS MAIL, U.S. POSTAGE, POSTAGE PAID, PERMIT 155 A postage meter mark consisting of a circular postmark on the left with "FARMINGDALE N.Y." and a rectangular postage paid indicia on the right with "FIRST CLASS MAIL U.S. POSTAGE POSTAGE PAID PERMIT 155", positioned centrally in the image.::> WILLIAM J DARBY MD % NUTRITION FOUNDATION 489 FIFTH AVE NEW YORK NY 10017 Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/gknp0227 Metropolitan Opera Photos: James Heffernan Holley Flagg Design Fidelio, Bellini's Norma, Bizet's Carmen, Humperdinck's Hansel and Gretel, Massenet's Werther, Mozart's Die Zauberflöte, Poulenc's Dialogues of the Carmelites, Strauss' Ariadne auf Naxos and Elektra, Verdi's Aida and Luisa Miller, and Wagner's Parsifal. **Christmas and Easter at the Met** Two revivals have special connections with the holiday seasons. *Hansel and Gretel* will be heard at the Christmas and New Year's holiday period. *Parsifal* will be performed several times during the Easter holidays.

Verdi's Don Carlo will open on February 5, 1979, also at a Guild Benefit. The conductor is James Levine, and the director John Dexter, with sets by David Reppa, costumes by Ray Diffen, and lighting by Gil Wechsler. Wagner's Der Fliegende Holländer, opening on March 8, 1979. Carol Neblett will make her Metropolitan debut as Senta and José van Dam will sing the Dutchman, with William Lewis as Erik and Paul Plishka as Daland.

## Revivals Nineteen operas will be revived during the 1978-79 season. Seven will be held over from the 93rd season: Tchaikovsky's *Eugene Onegin*, Puccini's *Madama Butterfly* and *Tosca*, Verdi's *Otello*, *Rigoletto*, and *La Traviata*, and Wagner's *Tannhäuser*.
The 12 works returning after an absence of one season or more will be: Beethoven's

<::A black and white photograph shows two images. The main image depicts a man, Jon Vickers, in costume as Otello, kneeling on a stage. He is wearing a long, patterned robe and has a beard, looking upwards with a dramatic expression. Behind him are two large, ornate, circular shields. In the bottom right corner, an inset photograph shows a woman, Marilyn Horne, from the chest up, looking slightly to the right. She has short, dark hair and is wearing a necklace. : photograph::> Verdi's Otello, with Jon Vickers in the title role, was revived during the current season, and will return in 1978-79. <::A circular, ornate metal object with a central raised boss and an intricately patterned border, resembling a shield or decorative plate.: figure::>

## Debuts In addition to the debut artists listed above with the new productions, the following musicians will be heard for the first time at the Met next season: conductors Yuri Siminov and Calvin Simmons; sopranos Makvala Kash-rashvili, Carol Malone, Mariana Niculescu, and May Sandoz; tenors Vladimir Atlantov, Peter Hofmann, and Seth McCoy; baritones Christian Boesch, Dale Duesing, Yuri Mazurok, and Siegmund Nimsgern; and basses Michael Devlin and Kurt Moll.
The publication of this Newsletter is made possible by a special grant from Pioneer High Fidelity.
Metropolitan Opera Lincoln Center New York, New York 10023

Fidelio, Bellini's Norma, Bizet's Carmen, Humperdinck's Hansel and Gretel, Massenet's Werther, Mozart's Die Zauberflöte, Poulenc's Dialogues of the Carmelites, Strauss' Ariadne auf Naxos and Elektra, Verdi's Aida and Luisa Miller, and Wagner's Parsifal.

**Christmas and Easter at the Met** Two revivals have special connections with the holiday seasons. *Hansel and Gretel* will be heard at the Christmas and New Year's holiday period. *Parsifal* will be performed several times during the Easter holidays.
